title: State v. Montgomery
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Laurtrent M.
          Montgomery, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lancaster County
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-602
  Submitted September 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
November 3, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Katherine H. Hudgins, Appellate Defender, South Carolina
          Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
          Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney
          General, of Columbia for Respondent; and Solicitor Douglas A. Barfield, Jr., of
          Lancaster, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Laurtrent M. Montgomery appeals his
  conviction for second-degree burglary, arguing the trial court erred in failing
  to dismiss the charge on double jeopardy grounds.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Montgomery was accused of breaking and entering into a home and
  an adjacent shed located nearby on the same property.Â  He was charged with
  first-degree burglary for entering the house and second-degree burglary for
  entering the shed.Â  At trial, Montgomery moved to have the second-degree
  burglary charge dismissed arguing the double jeopardy clause prevented him from
  receiving multiple punishments for the same offense.Â  Montgomery contended that
  under section 16-11-10 of the South Carolina Code (2003), the house and the
  shed constituted â€œone parcel.â€Â  Therefore, he argued he should only be charged
  with the single charge of first-degree burglary.Â  The trial court denied the
  motion.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Montgomery argues that under section 16-11-10 of the South
  Carolina Code (2003), the house and the shed constituted â€œone parcel.â€Â 
  Therefore, the act of breaking into the house and the shed constituted one
  offense.Â  Under the theory of double jeopardy, he could not be given multiple
  punishments for one offense.Â  We disagree.Â  
Section
  16-11-10 provides:

  With
    respect to the crimes of burglary and arson and to all criminal offenses which
    are constituted or aggravated by being committed in a dwelling house, any
    house, outhouse, apartment, building, erection, shed or box in which there
    sleeps a proprietor, tenant, watchman, clerk, laborer or person who lodges there
    with a view to the protection of property shall be deemed a dwelling house, and
    of such a dwelling house or of any other dwelling house all houses, outhouses,
    buildings, sheds and erections which are within two hundred yards of it and are
    appurtenant to it or to the same establishment of which it is an appurtenance
    shall be deemed parcels.

To
  adopt Montgomeryâ€™s interpretation of the statute strains the bounds of
  reasonableness.Â  The statute does not indicate that a dwelling house and a shed
  or other appurtenance constitute one unit with regard to the crime of
  burglary.Â  The statue merely indicates that such appurtenances are considered
  dwellings in the same manner that a house is considered a dwelling.Â  Therefore,
  if a defendant is accused of breaking into such a structure, he can be charged
  with breaking into a dwelling.
State
  v. Evans, 18 S.C. 137 (1882),
  discussed the former version of this statute which made appurtenant structures â€œdwellings.â€Â 
  The supreme court stated that the â€œstatute was intended to enlarge the field
  within which burglary could be committed.â€Â  Id.Â  That seems to be the
  consistent purpose of treating sheds, garages, porches and other appurtenant
  structures as dwellings.Â  There is no indication in the current statute to
  suggest the legislature meant to somehow contract the field within which
  burglary may be committed by making nearby structures and homes one indivisible
  unit.
Â Â 
  Furthermore, section 16-11-310 of the South Carolina Code (2003) states that
  â€œ[w]here a building consists of two or more units separately occupied or
  secured, each unit is deemed both a separate building in itself and a part of
  the main building.â€Â  Under this statute, a single building can be the site of
  multiple burglaries provided there are separately secured units within the
  building.Â  If that is the case, it would be illogical to assume section
  16-11-10 intended to make two free-standing, separately-secured structures a
  single building for purposes of the burglary statute.
Based
  on all of the foregoing, the ruling of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.

Anderson, Williams,
  and Konduros, JJ., concur.


[1] This case was decided without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM: Jules
  S. appeals from the family courtâ€™s order
  terminating his parental rights to his three minor children.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2007).Â  Upon a thorough review
  of the record and the family courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law,
  pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), we
  find no meritorious issues warrant briefing.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family
  courtâ€™s ruling and relieve counsel. 
AFFIRMED.[1]

title: State v. Davis
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      The State, Appellant,
      v.
      Jenny Davis, Respondent,
    
  


Appeal from Laurens County
  Honorable Frank R. Addy, Jr., Acting Circuit
Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-604
  Submitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed
November 6, 2008 

REVERSED


  
    
      
        John Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Kathrine H. Hudgins, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â This case involves the interpretation of
  the Sex Offender Accountability and Protection of Minors Act (the Act).Â  The
  State appeals the probation judgeâ€™s imposition of global positioning satellite
  monitoring (GPS) on Jenny Davis for the duration of her probation.Â  We reverse. [1]
FACTS
On
  December 2, 2004, Davis pleaded guilty to lewd act upon a child under sixteen. Â The
  trial court sentenced Davis to six yearsâ€™ imprisonment suspended upon the
  service of time served and three yearsâ€™ probation.Â  
Davis subsequently
  committed a series of probation violations. Â After a probation violation
  hearing, the probation judge revoked three months of Davisâ€™s suspended
  sentence, continued her probation, and placed her on GPS monitoring
  during the term of her probation. Â The State responded that because Davis pled guilty to lewd act on a child under sixteen, the Act requires monitoring for
  the duration Davis is required to remain on the sex offender registry.Â  The
  probation judge expressed concerns with lifetime GPS monitoring and ordered the
  monitoring only during the term of Davisâ€™s probation.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW / ANALYSIS
The State argues the probation judge erred in imposing GPS
  monitoring on Davis for a period of time less than the duration Davis is required to remain on the sex offender registry.Â  We agree.Â Â Â Â Â  
Section
  23-3-540(C) of the Act provides: â€œA person who is required to register pursuant
  to this article for . . . committing or attempting a lewd act upon a child
  under sixteen, pursuant to Section 16-15-140, and who violates a term of
  probation . . . must be ordered by the court or agency with jurisdiction to be
  monitored . . . with an active electronic monitoring device.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  23-3-540(C) (Supp. 2007).Â  â€œThe person shall be monitored . . . for the
  duration of the time the person is required to remain on the sex offender
  registry. . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-540(H) (Supp. 2007)
  (emphasis added).Â  
â€œWhen
  a statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for
  statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its
  literal meaning.â€Â  Miller v. Aiken, 364 S.C. 303, 307, 613 S.E.2d
  364, 366 (2005).Â  The word â€œshallâ€ indicates the time period set forth in Â§
  23-3-540(H) is mandatory.Â  See State v. Foster, 277 S.C.
  211, 212, 284 S.E.2d 780, 780 (1981) (â€œTaken literally, the word â€˜shallâ€™
  is mandatory.â€).Â  Accordingly, the probation judge lacked discretion to shorten
  the duration of Davisâ€™s electronic monitoring.[2]Â  
REVERSED. 
HEARN,
C.J., SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  We note Â§ 23-3-540(H) permits a person to petition
  for release from the monitoring requirements ten years from the date electronic
monitoring is imposed.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-540(H) (Supp. 2007).

title: Brinton v. Halsey
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Margaret Tavish
          Halsey Brinton, Appellant,
        v.
        The Estate of
          Ashley Halsey, Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
  Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-605
  Submitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed
November 6, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James Ross Snell, Jr. and Richard J. Breibart, both of Lexington, for Appellant.
        Mark D. Bower, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Margaret
  Tavish Halsey Brinton filed a claim against the estate of Ashley Halsey, Jr. (the Estate), requesting reimbursement for storing a
  mobile home owned by the Estate.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Following a hearing, the probate court issued an
  order denying Brintonâ€™s claim and modifying and approving final settlement of
  the Estate.Â  Brinton appealed to the circuit court, and the circuit court
  affirmed.Â  This appeal followed.Â  We
  affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As
  to the question whether the circuit court erred in affirming the probate
  courtâ€™s finding that Brintonâ€™s claim against the Estate was untimely: Camp
    v. Camp, 378 S.C. 237, 240, 662
  S.E.2d 458, 459-460 (Ct. App. 2008) (stating a motion to reconsider,
  alter, or amend judgment under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, that fails to specifically
  set forth the grounds for the motion is insufficient under Rule 7(b)(1),
  SCRCP); Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 235, 612
  S.E.2d 719, 726 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding an issue is not preserved for
  appellate review where the trial court does not explicitly rule on it and the
  appellant does not raise it in a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment); In re
    Timmerman, 331 S.C. 455, 460, 502 S.E.2d 920, 922 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œThe
  South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure are applicable in the probate court to
  the extent they are not inconsistent with the Probate Code or probate court
  rules. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-304 (1987); Rule 81, SCRCP. A motion to alter or
  amend a judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e),
  SCRCP, is not inconsistent with the Probate Code and is therefore applicable.â€).
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As to
  the question whether the circuit court erred in affirming the probate courtâ€™s
  approval of the sale of the mobile home for approximately $7,000, the
  distribution of the antique firearms, and the personal representativeâ€™s fees: Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP (stating a motion presented in
  writing â€œshall state with particularity the grounds therefor, and shall set
  forth the relief or order soughtâ€); Owners Ins. Co. v. Clayton, 364 S.C.
  555, 563, 614 S.E.2d 611, 615 (2005) (â€œError without prejudice does not warrant reversal.â€); Camp v. Camp, 378
  S.C. 237, 240, 662 S.E.2d 458, 459-460 (Ct. App. 2008) (stating a motion
  to reconsider, alter, or amend judgment under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, that fails to
  specifically set forth the grounds for the motion is insufficient under Rule
  7(b)(1), SCRCP); Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222,
  235, 612 S.E.2d 719, 726 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding an issue is not preserved for
  appellate review where the trial court does not explicitly rule on it and the
  appellant does not raise it in a Rule 59(e)
  motion to alter or amend the judgment). Â Â Â 
3.Â Â Â  As to the question whether the transcript of the probate
  court hearing was sufficient to allow proper review of the issues raised in
  this appeal: State v. Ladson, 373 S.C. 320, 324-25, 644 S.E.2d 271, 273 (Ct.
  App. 2007) (holding generally the inability to prepare a complete transcript,
  in and of itself, does not necessarily present a sufficient ground for reversal); see also State v. Williams, 629 A.2d 402, 406 (Conn. 1993)
  (holding appellant must show â€œspecific prejudice that results from having to
  address his claims on appeal with the reconstructed recordâ€); Harris v. Commâ€™r of Corr., 671 A.2d
  359, 363 (Conn. App. 1996). (â€œ[B]efore a defendant can establish that he is
  entitled to a new trial on the basis of an inadequate reconstructed record, he must identify a specific appellate claim
  that this court would be unable to review effectively using the reconstructed record.â€); Jones v. State, 923 So.2d 486, 489
  (Fla. 2006) (noting appellant must point to prejudice
  resulting from missing portions of trial transcript); Simpson v.
    Commonwealth, 759 S.W.2d 224, 228 (Ky. 1988) (holding a showing of
  â€œprejudicial errorâ€ in having to proceed using substitute transcript is
  required); State v. Bolling, 246 S.E.2d 631, 637-638 (W.Va. 1978)
  (â€œGenerally, the failure to report some part of the proceeding will not alone
  constitute reversible error.Â  Some identifiable error or prejudice must be
  shown by the defendant.â€). 
AFFIRMED.

HEARN,
C.J., SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Charleston
          County Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Serena B. and
          Gerald B. Defendants,
        Of Whom Gerald
          B. is the Appellant.
        In the interests of three minor children.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Jeffrey Young, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-606
  Submitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed
November 6, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stanley C.
          Rodgers, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Frampton Durban Jr., of North Charleston, for Respondent.
        Suzanne E. Groff, Guardian Ad Litem. of Charleston.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Gerald
  B. appeals from the family courtâ€™s order finding the pendency of his
  application for post-conviction relief does not authorize him to attack the
  facts underlying the offenses to which he pled guilty.Â  We affirm pursuant to
  Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities: Doe v. Doe,
  346 S.C. 145, 149, 551 S.E.2d 257, 259 (2001) (stating the burden of proof in a
  criminal proceeding is much higher than the burden of proof in a civil
  proceeding); State v. Allen, 261 S.C. 448, 451, 200 S.E.2d 684, 686 (1973)
  (asserting a plea of guilty is an admission of guilt that is as
  conclusive as the verdict of a jury); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-430 (Supp. 2007)[1] (requiring any person residing in
  South Carolina, who pleads guilty to specified criminal sexual offenses, to
  register as a sexual offender); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(2)(b) (Supp. 2007)[2] (â€œâ€˜Child
  abuse or neglect,â€™ or â€˜harmâ€™ occurs when the parent, guardian, or other person
  responsible for the childâ€™s welfare . . . engages in acts or omissions that present a
  substantial risk that a sexual offense as defined in the laws of this State
  would be committed against the child . . . .â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-650(L)(1) (Supp. 2007)[3] (requiring the court to enter a personâ€™s name in the Central Registry of Child Abuse
  and Neglect when it finds by a preponderance of evidence that the person
  physically or sexually abused a child). 
AFFIRMED.[4] 
HEARN,
C.J., SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1]Amended by Act No. 335, 2008 S.C. Acts 3311,
  which added provisions to address registration requirements for pardoned sex
offenders. 
[2]Repealed by Act No. 361, 2008 S.C. Acts 3623,
  which created Title 63 and transferred provisions from Chapter 7, Title 20 to
Title 63.Â  
[3]Repealed by Act No. 361, 2008 S.C. Acts
  3623, which created Title 63 and transferred provisions from Chapter 7, Title
20 to Title 63. 
[4]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

title: DeWitt v. Charleston Gas Light, Inc.
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

<!-- meta anti cache-->

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Merrill DeWitt, Respondent,
        v.
        Charleston Gas Light, Inc. and Debra M. McKinley,
          Individually and d/b/a Charleston Gas Light, Inc., Defendants,
        Of Whom
          Charleston Gas Light, Inc. is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-607
  Submitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed
November 6, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Allan R. Holmes, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Alan D. Toporek, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this breach of
  employment contract action, Debra McKinley argues the trial court erred in
  failing to grant her motion for directed verdict based on her good faith belief
  that cause existed to terminate Merrill DeWittâ€™s employment.Â  Additionally,
  McKinley argues she should be afforded a new trial, and she contends a rule
  requiring only a good faith belief in cause for termination should apply to all
  employment contracts, not only unilateral contracts.Â  We affirm pursuant to
  Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:
1.Â  As to the
  question of whether the trial court erred in denying McKinleyâ€™s motions for directed
  verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV):Â  McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367 S.C. 559, 564, 626 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2006) and Curcio v. Caterpillar, Inc., 355 S.C. 316, 320, 585 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2003)
  (both holding when reviewing a circuit
  courtâ€™s ruling on a directed verdict or JNOV, this court will reverse the
  ruling only when no evidence supports the ruling); Connor v. City of Forest Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 464, 560 S.E.2d 606, 611 (2002)
  (â€œThe appropriate test on the issue of breach is as follows: If the fact
    finder finds a contract to terminate only for cause, he must determine
  whether the employer had a reasonable good faith belief that sufficient
  cause existed for termination.â€) (internal quotations omitted) (first emphasis
added).
2.Â  As to whether
  the trial court erred in denying McKinleyâ€™s request for a new trial based on
  the jurorsâ€™ failure to comply with the trial courtâ€™s jury instructions:Â  In
    re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may
  not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for
  appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€); Lucas v.
    Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004)
  (â€œIt is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an
  appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon
by the trial court.â€).Â  
3.Â 
  As to whether the rule requiring only a reasonable good faith belief in cause
  for termination should apply to all employment contracts, not just unilateral
  contracts:Â  In re Michael H., 360 S.C. at 546, 602 S.E.2d at 732 (â€œAn
  issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an
  issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€); Lucas
    v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. at 510-11, 598 S.E.2d at 715 (â€œIt is
  well settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate
  court cannot address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the
  trial court.â€).
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and
  THOMAS, JJ., concur.

title: Burwell v. Ponderosa, Inc.
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Jeremy Scott
          Burwell, Appellant,
        v.
        Ponderosa, Inc.
          d/b/a Pirate Land Campground, Employer, and The Hartford, Carrier, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-608
  Submitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed
November 6, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        C. Daniel Vega, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        John McIntyre Tolar and Weston Adams, III, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jeremy Scott
  Burwell appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order denying coverage because he failed to
  provide his employer, Pirate Land Campground (Employer), with timely notice of
  the injuries he sustained.Â  Specifically, he argues the circuit court erred in
  affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s order because 1) Employer had notice in fact of
  his injuries; 2) Burwell provided a reasonable excuse for failing to give
  notice; and 3) Employer was not prejudiced from the late notice.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the
  following authorities.Â 
1.Â  As to the
  question of whether the Appellate Panel erred in finding Burwell failed to
  provide timely notice:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (A) (Supp. 2007) (requiring injured
  employees give notice to employers of an accident â€œunless it can be shown that
  the employer . . . had knowledge of the accident . . . .â€); S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§42-15-20 (B) (Supp. 2007) (â€œ[N]o compensation shall be payable unless such
  notice is given within ninety days after the occurrence of the accident . . .
  .â€); Lizee v. S.C. Dept. of Mental Health, 367 S.C. 122, 127, 623 S.E.2d
  860, 863 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding the claimant bears the burden of proving
  compliance with the statutory notice requirements); Rogers v. Kunja Knitting
    Mills, Inc., 312 S.C. 377, 380, 440 S.E.2d 401, 403 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œThe
  final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded
  evidence is reserved to the [Appellate Panel] and it is not the task of the
  [appellate] court to weigh the evidence as found by the [Appellate Panel].â€).
2.Â  As to whether
  the Appellate Panel erred in finding Burwell did not provide a reasonable
  excuse for failing to provide notice:Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§42-15-20 (B)
  (Supp. 2007) (asserting unless injured employees give notice within ninety days
  of the accident â€œno compensation shall be payable . . . unless reasonable
  excuse is made to the satisfaction of the [Appellate Panel] for not giving
  timely notice, and the [Appellate Panel] is satisfied that the employer has not
  been prejudiced therebyâ€).Â 
3.Â  As to whether
  the Appellate Panel erred in finding Employer was prejudiced:Â  Gray v. Laurens Mills, 231 S.C. 488, 492, 99 S.E.2d 36, 38
  (1957) (â€œ[L]ack of prejudice does not justify compensation unless the
  requirement of reasonable excuse is also satisfied.â€); see also Ringer v. Graham, 286 S.C.
  14, 20, 331 S.E.2d 373, 377 (Ct. App. 1985) (determining discussion of
  remaining issues was unnecessary after reversing a directed verdict).Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and
  THOMAS, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Kevin Thompson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-609
  Submitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed
November 6, 2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; Solicitor Douglas A.
          Barfield, Jr., of Lancaster, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Kevin Thompson appeals his conviction for possession of crack cocaine
  with intent to distribute and possession of cocaine with intent to distribute.Â 
  Thompson also appeals guilty pleas to five other drug charges he made during
  his sentencing hearing for his drug convictions.Â  Specifically, Thompson argues
  the trial court erred in admitting certain evidence and refusing to grant his
  motion for a mistrial.Â  Further, Thompson argues his guilty pleas should be
  vacated because his trial convictions should be vacated.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities: Â 
1.Â 
  As to whether the trial court erred in admitting evidence and failing to grant
  a mistrial:Â  State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 510, 476 S.E.2d 903, 912
  (1996) (â€œNo issue is preserved for appellate review if the objecting party
  accepts the [courtâ€™s] ruling and does not contemporaneously make an additional
  objection to the sufficiency of the curative charge or move for a mistrial.â€); State
    v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 226, 522 S.E.2d 845, 850 (Ct. App. 1999)
  (â€œBecause a trial courtâ€™s curative instruction is considered to cure any error
  regarding improper testimony, a party must contemporaneously object to a
  curative instruction as insufficient or move for a mistrial to preserve an
  issue for review.â€).Â  
2.Â 
  As to Thompsonâ€™s guilty pleas:Â  State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 108,
  292 S.E.2d 598, 599 (1982) (holding absent timely objection at plea proceeding,
  unknowing and involuntary nature of guilty plea can be attacked only through
  post-conviction relief); State v. Truesdale, 278 S.C. 368, 370, 296
  S.E.2d 528, 529 (1982); (â€œPleas of guilty are unconditional, and if an
  accused attempts to attach any condition or qualification thereto, the trial
  court should direct a plea of not guilty.â€).Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Alphonso Scott appeals the trial courtâ€™s
  dismissal of his request for injunctive relief for failure to state a claim
  pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, and other issues relating to the dismissal.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities: Spence v. Spence, 368 S.C. 106, 116, 628 S.E.2d 869, 874 (2006) (stating in
  deciding whether the trial court properly granted the motion to dismiss, the

Williams, Pieper,
  and Geathers, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] As dismissal pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6) is
  dispositive, we need not address the other issues relating to the trial courtâ€™s

title: Hampton v. Hunt Assisted Living
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Teresa Hampton,
          Employee, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Hunt Assisted
          Living, LLC d/b/a Greenville Place Assisted Living, Employer, and Key Risk
          Insurance Co., Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-630
  Heard October 22, 2008 â€“ Filed November
12, 2008Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        David A. Wilson and Michael A. Farry, both of Greenville, for
          Appellants.
        KathrynÂ  Williams, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Teresa Hampton brought this workersâ€™ compensation case
  seeking benefits for an injury resulting from a fall at work.Â  The Appellate
  Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Appellate Panel) denied
  compensation.Â  The circuit court reversed.Â  Hamptonâ€™s employer, Hunt Assisted
  Living d/b/a Greenville Place Assisted Living (Hunt), and Huntâ€™s carrier, Key
  Risk Insurance Company (collectively Appellants), appeal.Â  We reverse.
FACTS / PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Hampton began working for Hunt in June 2004 as a certified nursing assistant. Â She subsequently
  took a position in the kitchen as a cook. Â On October 25, 2004, after sitting
  at a table looking through menus, Hampton stood up and took a step with her
  right foot. Â When she began to take a step with her left foot, her ankle
  â€œtwistedâ€ or â€œcurled overâ€ causing her to fall to the floor. Â Hampton continued to work for an hour, but then went to the hospital because of severe
  pain in her left leg. Â Hampton was diagnosed at the hospital with left ankle
  sprain.Â  Dr. George Pattis examined Hampton about a week after her fall.Â  Dr.
  Pattis opined Hampton suffered from left ankle sprain and left foot
  tendonitis.Â  Dr. Pattis also noted Hampton suffered from right ankle ligaments
  strain from overuse of the right leg.Â  Hampton returned to work in November
  2004.Â  Later that month, Hunt terminated Hamptonâ€™s employment for
  insubordination.
Hampton subsequently brought this workersâ€™ compensation action seeking temporary total
  disability benefits and payment of past and continuing medical care. Â The
  single commissioner denied Hamptonâ€™s claim, holding Hamptonâ€™s injuries were not
  connected to or caused by her employment with Hunt. Â The Appellate Panel
  affirmed and adopted the order of the single commission in its entirety. Â Hampton then appealed to the circuit court. Â The circuit court reversed, holding Hampton
  sustained a compensable injury by accident as defined in the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Act and remanding the claim to the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commission (the Commission) to determine the extent of medical and compensation
  benefits.Â  
This appeal followed.Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
Appellants
  argue the circuit court erred in holding Hampton sustained a compensable injury
  by accident as defined in the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act (the Act).Â  Specifically,
  Appellants contend Hamptonâ€™s injuries are not compensable because Hampton failed to show a causal connection between her fall and her employment.Â 
  Appellants assert Hamptonâ€™s injuries resulted from an idiopathic or unexplained
  fall.Â  We agree.
In
  reviewing workersâ€™ compensation decisions, the appellate court ascertains
  â€œwhether the circuit court properly determined whether the appellate panelâ€™s
  findings of fact are supported by substantial evidence in the record and
  whether the panelâ€™s decision is affected by an error of law.â€  Baxter
    v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006)
  (citations omitted); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp.
  2007).  â€œâ€˜Substantial evidenceâ€™ is evidence which, considering the entire
  record, would allow reasonable minds to arrive at the same conclusion reached
  by the administrative agency.â€  S.C. Second Injury Fund v. Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 353 S.C. 117, 122, 576 S.E.2d 199, 202 (Ct. App. 2003). 
  The Administrative Procedures Act does not permit an appellate court to â€œsubstitute
  its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on
  questions of fact.â€  West v. Alliance Capital, 368 S.C. 246, 251,
  628 S.E.2d 279, 282 (Ct. App. 2006). 
An
  injury is compensable under the Act if it occurs accidentally, â€œarising out of
  and in the course of employment.â€  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160(A) (Supp.
  2007).Â  â€œAn injury arises out of employment when there is apparent to the
  rational mind, upon consideration of all the circumstances, a causal
  relationship between the conditions under which the work is to be performed and
  the resulting injury.â€Â  Owings v. Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Dept., 315
  S.C. 297, 299, 433 S.E.2d 869, 871 (1993).Â  Further, â€œif the injury can be seen
  to have followed as a natural incident of the work and as a result of the
  exposure occasioned by the nature of the employment, then it arises out of the
  employment.â€Â  Holley v. Owens Corning Fiberglas Corp., 301 S.C. 519,
  523, 392 S.E.2d 804, 807 (Ct. App. 1990).
Specific rules
  relating to idiopathic or unexplained falls, however, modify the general ruling
  of compensability.Â  An unexplained fall is generally not compensable unless the
  employment contributed to either the cause or the effect of the fall.  Bagwell
    v. Ernest Burwell, Inc., 227 S.C. 444, 452-53, 88 S.E.2d 611, 614-15 (1955). 
  The causative danger â€œneed not have been foreseen or expected, but after the
  event it must appear to have had its origin in a risk connected with the
  employment, and to have flowed from that source as a rational consequence.â€Â  West
    v. Alliance Capital, 368 S.C. 246, 252, 628 S.E.2d 279, 282 (Ct. App. 2006)
  (internal citations omitted).  Injuries are excluded from compensability
  under the Act when they come â€œfrom a hazard to which the workmen would have
  been equally exposed apart from the employment.â€  Crosby v.
    Wal-Mart Store, Inc., 330 S.C. 489, 493, 499 S.E.2d 253, 255 (Ct. App.
  1998).  â€œThe burden is on the claimant to prove such facts as will render
  the injury compensable, and such an award must not be based on surmise, conjecture
  or speculation.â€ Id. at 496, 499 S.E.2d at 257.
The
  facts in this case are very similar to the facts set forth in Crosby,
  330 S.C. 489, 499 S.E.2d 253.Â  In Crosby, the claimant, a Wal-Mart
  employee, sought benefits for injuries she received when she fell at work.Â  The
  claimant testified she fell while walking through the store on the way to a
  meeting. Id. at 491, 499 S.E.2d at 254.Â  She stated, â€œI was just walking
  on the floor and my feet went from under me.â€Â  Id.Â  This court
  determined the claimantâ€™s fall was an unexplained fall.Â  We stated, â€œ[T]here
  was no evidence offered in the case at hand as to what caused [the claimant] to
  fall.Â  It would be wholly conjectural to say under the evidence presented that
  [the claimantâ€™s] employment was a contributing cause of her injury.â€Â  Id. at 495, 499 S.E.2d at 256.Â  This court further reasoned that, while the fall was
  unexplained, there was an apparent lack of work connection and an implication
  of a pre-existing physical condition.Â  Id. at 496, 499 S.E.2d at 257.
  This court concluded there was substantial evidence to support the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s finding that claimant failed to show a causal connection between her
  fall and her employment.Â  Id.
Here,
  Hampton fell when she stood up from a table and began to walk.Â  Like the
  claimant in Crosby, Hampton could not explain the reason for her fall.Â  Hampton testified her ankle simply â€œtwistedâ€
  or â€œcurled over.â€Â  Although Hampton was involved in work duties when she fell,
  no evidence indicates her employment contributed to the cause or the effect of
  her fall.Â  As set forth above, the burden is on Hampton to establish facts
  showing her injury is compensable.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the circuit court
  and find substantial evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding Hamptonâ€™s injuries were not connected to or caused by her employment.
REVERSED.Â  
HUFF and
  GEATHERS, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Wayne S.
          Tippett, Appellant,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Corrections, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From the Administrative Law Court
  Â John D. Geathers, Administrative Law
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-631
  Submitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed
November 12, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Wayne
          S. Tippett, pro se, for Appellant.
        Robert
          Wesley Jacobs, of Columbia, for Respondent.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Wayne S. Tippett was convicted of armed robbery in
  1972 and sentenced to twenty-five yearsâ€™ imprisonment with hard labor.Â  Tippett
  escaped in 1972 and again in 1976, returning to custody in South Carolina in
  2002.Â  Tippett appeals the Administrative Law Courtâ€™s denial of his grievance contesting
  a disciplinary conviction of â€œescapeâ€ following his 1976 escape and its
  dismissal of his grievances contesting the loss of twenty days of good time
  following the 1972 escape, the denial of sentence credits for the time he
  served in a Utah county jail while contesting extradition, and the unlawful
  recalculation of his sentence term.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As
  to the issue of Tippettâ€™s disciplinary conviction of â€œescapeâ€ following his
  1976 escape:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  1-23-380(A)(4), 1-23-610(C) (Supp. 2007) (limiting review of a decision by the ALC
  to the record); Kearse v. State Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n,
  318 S.C. 198, 200, 456 S.E.2d 892, 893 (1995) (â€œThe findings of the agency are
  presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial
  evidence.â€). 
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As
  to the issue of the loss of twenty days of good time following Tippettâ€™s 1972
  escape:Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrs. v. Mitchell, 377 S.C. 256, 259, 659 S.E.2d
  233, 235 (Ct. App. 2008) (quoting Waters v. S.C. Land Res. Conservation Commâ€™n,
  321 S.C. 219, 226, 467 S.E.2d 913, 917 (1996)) (â€œThe burden is on appellants to
  prove convincingly that the agencyâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence.â€). 
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As
  to the issue of the denial of sentence credits for the time Tippett served in a
  Utah county jail while contesting extradition:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-40
  (2007); see also Delahoussaye v. State, 369 S.C. 522, 528, 633
  S.E.2d 158, 161 (2006) (citing Oglesby v. Leeke, 263 S.C. 283, 210
  S.E.2d 232 (1974)) (recognizing a convict may earn sentence credits while in
  the custody of another jurisdiction, but excluding from eligibility for these
  credits a convict who finds himself in the other jurisdictionâ€™s custody
  following his escape from South Carolina custody).Â  Â Â 
4.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As
  to the issue of the unlawful recalculation of Tippettâ€™sÂ  sentence term:Â  Wright
    v. Marlboro County Sch. Dist., 317 S.C. 160, 164, 452 S.E.2d 12, 15 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œOrdinarily, the decision of an administrative tribunal precludes the
  relitigation of the issues addressed by that tribunal in a collateral action.â€).
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF and THOMAS, JJ., concur,


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Jerry F. Powell appeals his commitment under
  the South Carolina Sexually Violent Predator Act (the Act).Â  Powell argues the trial court erred in denying his motion to
  dismiss because the State failed to follow procedure in the Act.Â  We
  affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities: Â S.C. Code Â§
  44-48-80(A) (Supp. 2007) (â€œIf the court determines that probable cause exists
  to believe that the person is a sexually violent predator, the person must be
  taken into custody if he is not already confined in a secure facility.â€); S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(B) (Supp. 2007) (â€œThis [probable cause] hearing must be
  held within seventy-two hours after a person is taken into custody pursuant
    to subsection (A).â€) (emphasis added.); see also Hodges v. Rainey,
  341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000) (â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory
  construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature . . .
  . Where the statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear
  and definite meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and
  the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€).Â Â

ANDERSON, HUFF, and
  THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
	In The Court of Appeals
	
		
			
				
					Overnite
          Transportation, Appellant,
					v.
					South Carolina Second Injury Fund, Respondent,
					[IN RE: Kenneth
          Teaster, Employee/Claimant
					v.
					Overnite
          Transportation, Employer/Carrier.]
				
			
		
	
	
  Appeal From Spartanburg County
	Â Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge
  Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-639
	Submitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed
    November 17, 2008Â Â  
  AFFIRMED
  
	
		
			
				
					David Hill Keller, of Greenville, for Appellant.
					Latonya Dilligard Edwards, of Columbia, for Respondent.
				
			
		
	
  PER CURIAM: Overnite Transportation (Overnite) appeals from a
    circuit court order affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding Overnite was not
    entitled to reimbursement from the South Carolina Second Injury Fund (the Fund)
    for Kenneth Teasterâ€™s injuries.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:
  1.Â  As to whether Teasterâ€™s accidents involved physical injuries which
    resulted in the exacerbation of a pre-existing psychological condition: Stone
    v. Roadway Express, 367 S.C. 575, 582, 627 S.E.2d 695, 698 (2006)
    (stating an issue must be raised and ruled upon by the Appellate Panel in order
    to be considered on appeal).
  2.
    As to whether Teasterâ€™s mental injuries were entitled to compensation under the
    Workersâ€™ Compensation Act pursuant to South Carolina Code section 42-1-160(B):
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160(B) (Supp. 2007) (stating an employee must establish
    by a preponderance of the evidence stress, mental injuries, and mental illness
    arising out of and in the course of employment and unaccompanied by physical
    injury should be considered a personal injury); Gray v. Club Group, Ltd.,
    339 S.C. 173, 182, 528 S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App. 2000) (stating a reviewing
    court should affirm a decision by the Appellate Panel unless it is clearly
    erroneous in view of the substantial evidence of the whole record).
  3.Â  As to whether Teasterâ€™s mental injuries were reimbursable under South Carolina Code section
    42-9-400(d)(34)(b) (Supp. 2003):[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-400(a) (Supp. 2007) (stating if an employee has a
    permanent physical impairment and incurs a subsequent disability from an injury
    arising out of an in the course of his employment, an employer may be
    reimbursed by the Fund if certain statutory conditions are met); S.C. Code Ann.
    Â§ 42-9-400(d)(34)(b) (Supp. 2003) (explaining in order to qualify for reimbursement
    an employer must prove: (1) the employee had a pre-existing permanent physical
    impairment; (2) the employer had knowledge of employeeâ€™s permanent physical
    impairment; and (3) the pre-existing permanent impairmentÂ  combined with the
    subsequent injury to cause impairment in excess ofÂ  seventy-eight weeks under
    section 42-9-30).
  AFFIRMED.[3]
  WILLIAMS, PIEPER, and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] South Carolina Code section 42-9-400(d)(34)(b) (Supp.
  2003) was deleted by a 2007 amendment; however, it was applicable at the time
  of the alleged injury. 
[3] Overniteâ€™s argument that the circuit court
  engaged in impermissible fact finding is manifestly without merit, and we
  decline to address it.Â  Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Muriel V. Metts, Respondent,
				v.
				Charleston County Assessor, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From the Administrative Law Court
Â Paige J. Gossett, Administrative Law
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-640
Submitted November 3, 2008 - Filed
  November 17, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				County
  Attorney Joseph Dawson, III, Deputy County Attorney Bernard E. Ferrara, Jr.,
  and Assistant County Attorney Bernice M. Jenkins, all of North Charleston, for
  Appellant.
				Muriel
  V. Metts, pro se, of Sullivans Island, for Respondent
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: The Charleston County Assessor (Assessor) appeals from
  an order of the Administrative Law Court (ALC) granting Muriel V. Metts a
  four-percent special property tax assessment ratio.Â  Metts received the
  four-percent assessment ratio until 2006.Â  In 2005, the Legislature amended the
  tax assessment ratio statute to guarantee a four-percent assessment ratio for
  properties that otherwise qualified but were rented out for less than fifteen
  days during the tax year.Â  Because Metts rented her home out for 85 days in
  2006, the Assessor prepared her tax bill for that year using the higher
  six-percent assessment ratio.Â  
We
  affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities.Â  As to the
  question whether the ALC erred in its judgment:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610
  (Supp. 2007) (â€œThe review of the administrative law judgeâ€™s order must be
  confined to the recordâ€; appellate court may reverse the ALC if the ALCâ€™s
  decision is â€œaffected by [an] error of law.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-43-220(c)(1)
  (Supp. 2007) (â€œThe legal residence . . . [is] taxed on an assessment equal to
  four percent of the fair market value of the property.â€); S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 12-43-220(c)(2)(i) (Supp. 2007) (finding four percent assessment ratio
  applies when â€œthe owner-occupant [has] owned and occupied the residence as his
  legal residence and [has] been domiciled at that address for some period during
  the applicable tax yearâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-43-220(c)(7) (Supp. 2007)
  (renting out a residential property for fewer than fifteen days during the tax
  year does not preclude that property from receiving the four percent assessment
  ratio); and Russo v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 334 S.C. 455, 458, 513
  S.E.2d 127, 128 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œIn statutory construction, legislative intent
  prevails where it can be reasonably ascertained from the plain meaning of the statutory language.â€).Â  As to the question
  whether the ALC properly applied rules of statutory construction:Â  Aiken v.
    World Fin. Corp., 373 S.C. 144, 644 S.E.2d 705 (2007) (finding issues not
  raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not be considered on appeal).
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF,
  and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

  of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Joseph Wilson appeals his convictions for murder, criminal conspiracy,
  attempted armed robbery and possession of a weapon during a violent crime.Â  Wilson argues the trial court erred in: failing to charge the jury on accessory to murder;
  failing to charge the jury on manslaughter; allowing the state to proceed with
  both the charge of armed robbery and possession of a weapon during a violent
  crime; and granting the stateâ€™s motion to amend the date on the indictments.Â  After
  a thorough review of the record, counselâ€™s brief, and appellantâ€™s pro se brief pursuant
  to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams,
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss[1] Wilsonâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED. Â 
WILLIAMS, PIEPER, and GEATHERS, JJ., concur. 


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

In The Court of Appeals

				v.
				Marvin Pittman
      Erectors, Employer and South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund, Carrier,

				of whom Curtis
      Howard and Marvin Pittman Erectors are, Respondents,
				And
				South Carolina
      Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund is the Appellant.

ubmitted November 3, 2008 â€“ Filed

				Robert Merrell Cook, II, of Batesburg-Leesville, for Appellant.
				Michael S. Swindell, of Greenville; and Marvin Pittman, pro se, of
  Easley, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this
  workersâ€™ compensation case, South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund appeals
  the trial courtâ€™s ruling that Marvin Pittman Erectors was subject to the South
  Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act (the Act).Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities: S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  42-1-360(2) (Supp. 2007) (providing an employer that regularly employs fewer
  than four employees in the same business is exempt from the Act); Hernandez-Zuniga
    v. Tickle, 374 S.C. 235, 248, 647 S.E.2d 691, 698 (Ct. App. 2007)
  (contrasting â€œregular employmentâ€ with â€œcasual employment,â€ and defining
  â€œcasual employmentâ€ as occasional or by chance and not in the usual course of
  the employerâ€™s trade or business);Â  Id. at 245-46, 647 S.E.2d at 696-97
  (quoting 4 Larson, Workersâ€™ Compensation Â§Â§ 74.01-02 (addressing the minimum employee
  requirement and providing the number of employees working at the exact time of
  injury is immaterial)); Harding v. Plumley, 329 S.C. 580, 584, 496
  S.E.2d 29, 31 (Ct. App. 1998) (providing the issue of whether an employer
  regularly employs the requisite number of employees is jurisdictional;
  therefore, the appellate court is not bound by the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings
  of fact and resolves the issue by determining whether the preponderance of
  evidence supports inclusion under the Act); Grouse v. DRB Baseball Mgmt.,
    Inc., 465 S.E.2d 568, 570 (N.C. App. 1996) (defining â€œregularly employedâ€
  as â€œemployment of the same number of persons throughout the period with some
  consistencyâ€). 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
